message.content:
We can try to “connect the dots” – but after writing out all the provided “is ancestor/descendant” facts and “chaining” them together, we find that the information splits into several unrelated “branches.” For example, one branch runs as follows:
 • “Megan is Alan’s ancestor” and “Alan is Cynthia’s ancestor” (because “Megan is Alan’s ancestor” [see fact 58] and “Alan is in the chain that goes through Cynthia, Samantha, Beverly, Robert to Brandon” – see facts 35, 3, 2, 16, and 32),
so we get
  Megan > Alan > Cynthia > Samantha > Beverly > Robert > Brandon.

In another branch a long chain is given that begins with Elijah:
 • “Elijah is Harold’s ancestor” (fact 24), then “Harold is Michael’s ancestor” (fact 39), “Bobby is Michael’s descendant” (fact 55), “Bobby is Philip’s ancestor” (fact 48), “Ralph is Philip’s descendant” (fact 13), and then further on the chain eventually reaches
  … > Denise > Patricia > Mason > Diana > Amy > Gabriel > Dorothy > Andrea > Mary > … 
—with many more names following.

None of the individuals in Brandon’s chain appear in the Elijah chain (nor does one appear as an ancestor/descendant of the other). In other words, no matter how you “follow the links” from Brandon upward or from Elijah downward, you never hit the other name. In particular, there is no indication that one is the other’s ancestor or descendant, and there is no single person who appears in both chains that would serve as a common descendant.

Even if one might suspect that all these names belong to one very extended, “merging‐at–some point” family tree, the facts we’re given do not actually connect Brandon’s branch to Elijah’s branch. (For instance, Brandon’s “top” is eventually reached via Megan, Alan, Cynthia, etc., whereas on the Elijah side the very first given relation is “Elijah is Harold’s ancestor” – and no fact tells us that Elijah, or any of his descendants, is related to any person in Brandon’s branch.)

Thus, among the answer choices:
 1. “Brandon and Elijah share a common descendant” – not supported.
 2. “Brandon and Elijah share a common ancestor” – nothing in the facts shows that their branches merge.
 3. “Brandon is Elijah’s descendant” – no.
 4. “Brandon is Elijah’s ancestor” – no.
 5. “None of the above is correct.”

Because the information does not support any direct connection between Brandon and Elijah, the correct answer is option 5.

<ANSWER>5</ANSWER>
